title: Jacob Elordi Teases â€˜Euphoriaâ€™ Season 3 as â€˜Incredibly Clever and Cinematicâ€™: â€˜It Wasâ€¦Liberatingâ€™
description:
Jacob Elordi is teasing the highly anticipated third season of â€œEuphoria.â€

	â€œIt was incredible, man,â€ the actor told me Saturday on the Academy Mus
body:
Jacob Elordi is teasing the highly anticipated third season of â€œEuphoria.â€

	â€œIt was incredible, man,â€ the actor told me Saturday on the Academy Museum Gala red carpet. â€œIt was incredibly liberating. I got to play something so sort of far out from what Iâ€™ve done before.â€

	He said that series creator Sam Levinson â€œconstructed something thatâ€™s incredibly clever and cinematic. I think people are really going to like it.â€
	

	However, Elordi insists he doesnâ€™t actually know exactly what happens in Season 3.

	â€œEverybody shoots at different storylines,â€ Elordi said. â€œI donâ€™t know what anyone else is doing. I had a really singular storyline. You donâ€™t know what the other story lines are. Itâ€™s like FBI files. So itâ€™s great because Iâ€™ll get to consume the show the same way that everybody else does as a fan, which I havenâ€™t been able to do before. Iâ€™m really excited.â€

	Elordi also wanted to clear up a news story that reported he said that Season 3 was entirely shot in VistaVision. â€œI did not say that, that is not true,â€ he said, adding, â€œItâ€™s shot on a lot of different kinds of film and itâ€™s beautiful.â€

	Reps at Warner Bros. did not respond to Varietyâ€˜s request for comment regarding the use of VistaVision. 

	â€œEuphoriaâ€ follows a group of high school students who orbit around Rue (Zendaya), a drug-addicted teenager who must navigate intense social dynamics, family drama and staying clean after rehabilitation. Season 2 aired in 2022. Across its first two seasons, the show received 25 Emmy nominations and won nine awards.
	

	In addition to Elordi, returning cast members include Zendaya, Hunter Schafer, Eric Dane, Sydney Sweeney, Alexa Demie, Maude Apatow, Martha Kelly, Chloe Cherry, Dominic Fike, Colman Domingo and Kika King.

	Trisha Paytas, Natasha Lyonne, Danielle Deadwyler and Eli Roth have joined for Season 3, as have Bella Podaras, Bill Bodner, Cailyn Rice, Colleen Camp, Gideon Adlon, Hemky Madera, Homer Gere, Jack Topalian, Jessica Blair Herman, Kwame Patterson, Madison Thompson, Matthew Willig, Rebecca Pidgeon and Sam Trammell.

	Elordi is currently in the midst of a promotional and awards campaign blitz for Guillermo del Toroâ€™s â€œFrankenstein.â€ Elordi stars in the Netflix film as the monster alongside Oscar Isaac as Victor Frankenstein.

	â€œ[Netflix CEO] Ted Sarandos said to me before I started the film, â€˜Youâ€™re so lucky youâ€™re going to get to work with a kind genius and thatâ€™s a rare thing,â€™â€ Elordi recalled. â€œA kind genius is a rare thing. He is the kindest of geniuses.â€

schema.headline: Jacob Elordi Teases â€˜Euphoriaâ€™ Season 3 as â€˜Incredibly Clever and Cinematicâ€™: â€˜It Wasâ€¦Liberatingâ€™

title: Box Office: â€˜Black Phone 2â€™ Grabs $26.5 Million in Otherwise Muted October Weekend
description: Universal and Blumhouseâ€™s horror sequel â€œBlack Phone 2â€ kicked off spooky season with $26.5 million from 3,411 North American theaters. Those ticket
body:
Universal and Blumhouseâ€™s horror sequel â€œBlack Phone 2â€ kicked off spooky season with $26.5 million from 3,411 North American theaters. Those ticket sales were enough to lead an otherwise sleepy weekend at the domestic box office.

	â€œBlack Phone 2â€ opened in line with expectations and slightly ahead of its predecessor. The original â€œBlack Phoneâ€ launched with $23 million in 2021 as cinemas were only starting to recover from COVID. Just to give a sense of the vastly different box office landscape between the first and second film: With similar ticket sales, â€œBlack Phoneâ€ opened in fourth place behind â€œElvis,â€ â€œTop Gun: Maverickâ€ and â€œJurassic World: Dominionâ€ in the height of summer movie season. 
	

	In contrast, the â€œBlack Phoneâ€ follow-up had a sluggish October weekend mostly to itself. This weekendâ€™s other newcomer, Lionsgateâ€™s R-rated comedy â€œGood Fortune,â€ opened at No. 3 with just $6.2 million from, 2990 venues. Second place went to Disneyâ€™s sci-fi sequel â€œTron: Areâ€ with $11.1 million from 4,000 screens, representing a steep 66% decline from its first outing. Right now the October box office is down 11% from the same point in 2024, according to Comscore.


	â€œBlack Phone 2â€ also collected $15.5 million at the international box office for a global tally of $42 million. Though a promising result, Universal and Blumhouse spent more to bring back Ethan Hawke as the serial killer known as the Grabber. The sequel cost $30 million compared to the first filmâ€™s $18 million price tag. â€œBlack Phone 2â€ has decent reviews but wasnâ€™t received as fondly as the original by moviegoers; this film earned a â€œBâ€ grade on CinemaScore exit polls while the first landed a â€œB+â€ grade. 
	

	â€œWeâ€™ve seen word-of-mouth grow over the weekend,â€ says Universalâ€™s president of domestic distribution Jim Orr. â€œThe reasons are simple: Blumhouse and director Scott Derrickson have crafted something thatâ€™s terrifying, with a great cast. Itâ€™s just what audiences want to see in theaters.â€

	Since ticket sales are split roughly 50-50 between studios and movie theaters, â€œBlack Phone 2â€ needs to stick around to count as a major comeback for Blumhouse. The low-budget horror empire, responsible for â€œParanormal Activity,â€ â€œThe Purge,â€ â€œGet Outâ€ â€œHalloweenâ€ and other franchises with scary-good profit margins, has long been one of Hollywoodâ€™s most consistent hitmakers. However the companyâ€™s fortunes have shifted over the past year with one dud after another including â€œWolf Manâ€ and â€œM3GAN 2.0.â€ Blumhouse has another sequel, â€œFive Nights at Freddyâ€™s 2,â€ on the calendar in December.

	â€œGood Fortuneâ€ has the good fortune of respectable reviews (78% on Rotten Tomatoes) and audience scores (a â€œB+â€ grade on CinemaScore. The trouble is that not enough people were incentivized to buy tickets for the $30 million-budgeted film. Aziz Ansari directed in his feature debut and stars in â€œGood Fortune,â€ which revolves around a good-intentioned but inept angel (Keanu Reeves) who facilitates a body swap between a struggling gig worker (Ansari) and a wealthy venture capitalist (Seth Rogen). 

	â€œThis is a fair opening for an original character-driven comedy,â€ says David A. Gross, who runs the movie consulting firm Franchise Entertainment Research.Â However â€œeven with Keanu Reeves helping ancillary business, the movie is unlikely to recoup its costs.â€

	Another film thatâ€™ll struggle to get out of the red is â€œTron: Ares.â€ So far the futuristic film has earned $54.6 million domestically and $103 million worldwide after two weekends of release. Although the $100 million mark is notable, Disney spent $180 million to produce and many millions to promote the sequel, so â€œTron: Aresâ€ requires substantial staying power to justify those costs.

	Channing Tatumâ€™s dramedy â€œRoofmanâ€ and Leonardo DiCaprioâ€™s action comedy â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ rounded out the top of box office charts.

	â€œRoofmanâ€ earned $3.7 million from 3,370 theaters in its second weekend, marking a 55% decline from its debut. So far the film has generated $15.5 million and $16.4 million worldwide, a paltry total albiet against a modest $18 million budget.
	

	â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ collected $3.75 million from 2,532 locations in its fourth outing, bringing its domestic total to $61 million. The Warner Bros. film, directed by Paul Thomas Anderson, has been a steady performer overseas with $100 million to date, bringing the global total to $162.5 million. Thatâ€™s an impressive figure for an original, R-rated film thatâ€™s nearly three hours long. 

	However the studio spent more than $130 million to produce and roughly $70 million to promote â€œOne Battle,â€ which requires about $300 million to break even. At this rate, the movie is tracking to lose $100 million in its theatrical run, according to studio executives with knowledge of the economics of similar-sized films. (Warner Bros. refutes those estimates.) â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ is, however, expected to be a major Oscar player, which makes it valuable to the company in ways beyond the balance sheet.Â 

	Elsewhere, director Luca Guadagninoâ€™s #MeToo-inspired thriller â€œAfter the Huntâ€ failed to sustain any traction while expanding nationwide. At No. 7, the movie brought in $1.56 million from 1,238 theaters. After one weekend in limited release, â€œAfter the Huntâ€ has amassed just $1.77 million, a dispiriting result for something led by major stars including Julia Roberts, Ayo Edebiri and Andrew Garfield.

	In limited release, Iranian director Jafar Panahiâ€™s Palme dâ€™Or winner â€œIt Was Just an Accidentâ€ scored $68,000 from three venues in New York City and Los Angeles, averaging $22,000 per location. The film, released by Neon and expected to be an awards contender, has grossed $115,000 since Wednesday. 

	Richard Linklaterâ€™s dramedy â€œBlue Moonâ€ didnâ€™t fare as well among speciality titles. The movie earned $67,060 from five locations, averaging $13,412 per screen. Hawke also stars in â€œBlue Moonâ€ (in a very different role from â€œBlack Phone 2â€) as songwriter Lorenz Hart as he reflects on the opening night of â€œOklahoma,â€ a new musical by his former collaborator Richard Rodgers.

schema.headline: Box Office: â€˜Black Phone 2â€™ Grabs $26.5 Million in Otherwise Muted October Weekend

title: Lucca Seen as a Place of Liberation and Community in Manlio Castagna Documentary: â€˜They Put on Masks to Show Their True Selvesâ€™
description: â€œI first came to Lucca in 2018, and I thought at the time, it was a sort of a carnival with a lot of people with strange costumes and stuff like tha
body:
â€œI first came to Lucca in 2018, and I thought at the time, it was a sort of a carnival with a lot of people with strange costumes and stuff like that,â€ film director Manlio Castagna tells Variety. â€œBut when I entered this incredible walled city, I had the feeling it was not just a carnival, but a place where people could be happy with their identities. Lucca Comics & Games is a place where people can be whatever they want to be. They put on masks to show their true selves.â€
	

	Castagna is the director of the new documentary â€œI Love Lucca Comics & Games,â€ a passionate love letter to the biggest comic convention in Europe. For five days, the medieval Italian town in the heart of Tuscany is transformed into a Cosplay Mecca, with book signings, artist events, screenings, exhibitions and concerts with over 300,000 visitors flooding onto the streets and piazzas.


	Using the metaphor of the Mandala, Castagnaâ€™s film builds a picture gradually piece by piece following the stories of the organizers, the artists and writers, the game designers and film directors, and the fans and how they interact.

	â€œThis is a movie about communities,â€ Castagna says. â€œItâ€™s a place where bridges are more important than walls. Itâ€™s important to show how gratitude, for example, is a sort of a glue between normal people, normal in quotation marks, normal people and the community and the artist, the guest.â€

	There are shots of fans meeting their favorite artists and writers, and what makes it moving is that outside their fandom the stars of the comic book or gaming scene might not be household names and so here they get a taste of the appreciation the fans feel. Having found compelling stories among the fans via social media, Castagna shot throughout the festival with two camera units. An editing bay was made available on site and the festival gave the director access to the VIPs and guests such as the best-selling authors R. L. Stine and Licia Troisi, the rapper Frankie Hi-NRG MC and the comic book artists Pera Toons, Sio, Yoshitaka Amano and Roberto Recchio. â€œThe first day we had a lot of rain and it was difficult but then the sun came out for the following days.â€
	

	One of the most moving stories in the film is the portrait of a father and son bonding over their love of geek culture. â€œIâ€™ve been going into schools for the last 25 years because I was the vice director of the Giffoni Film Festival for kids. So I connect with the young people, and Iâ€™ve seen with my own eyes, how this culture has changed over the years. At the beginning, when I started reading comics, Dungeons & Dragons, the role playing game, was only for a niche of people. In the schools, this kind of art was not seen in a very good way. For example, the two or three kids reading manga would get bullied. Now itâ€™s totally the opposite when I go into the classrooms, all the kids know about this: manga, anime, and D&D. Lucca Comics & Games is a window to see this change, but at the same time itâ€™s the engine of this transformation.â€

	Some of the people included in Castagnaâ€™s documentary have their lives transformed by the experience of Lucca. They meet their life partners; they come out; they find friendship and a community. â€œIn fact, the first title that popped up in my mind when I was filming was â€˜The Happiness Effect,â€™ because Lucca has this kind of effect on people. Lucca can affect you as a place full of magic and full of these incredible, special people. For example, people are in the lines for hours and hours, and they are always happy. There are a lot of people, and we never see fighting, or conflict. Itâ€™s a wonderful example of how society can be.â€

	Coming back to the metaphor of the Mandala highlighted in the film, Castagna explains: â€œLucca Comics & Games flourishes from the collective contribution of thousands of people: organizers, exhibitors, artists and the public. It is a collective ritual that, in its composition, reflects the patient construction of the festival itself. But, like the Mandala, the festival is also destined to dissolve. At the end, every element is dismantled, the squares return to emptiness, and the streets resume their rhythm. Nothing remains but the memory and the anticipation of the next edition, when the design can begin to take shape again.â€

	Lucca Comics & Games takes place from Oct. 29 to Nov. 2. I Wonder Pictures releases â€œI Love Lucca Comics & Gamesâ€ in Italy on Nov. 10.

schema.headline: Lucca Seen as a Place of Liberation and Community in Manlio Castagna Documentary: â€˜They Put on Masks to Show Their True Selvesâ€™

title: Donald Trump Posts Bizarre AI Video of Himself in a â€˜King Trumpâ€™ Fighter Jet  Bombing NYC Protestors With Streams of Brown Liquid
description:
President Donald Trump had a seemingly scatological reaction to the nationwide â€œNo Kingsâ€ protests against him Saturday.

	In an AI-generated video
body:
President Donald Trump had a seemingly scatological reaction to the nationwide â€œNo Kingsâ€ protests against him Saturday.

	In an AI-generated video Trump shared on his Truth Social platform Saturday evening, the U.S. president is depicted as a king in a fighter jet dropping what appears to be a large amount of fecal matter on protesters below. In the 19-second video, the president is in a fighter jet marked â€œKing Trump,â€ and he is shown wearing a crown sitting in the cockpit. (The oxygen mask that â€œKing Trumpâ€ wears does not fully cover his nose and mouth.)
	

	In the video, â€œKing Trumpâ€ appears to zoom the jet over New York City, whereupon he drops a bomb payload of brown sludge on the protesters in the streets below him. The video is set to â€œDanger Zone,â€ the Kenny Loggins hit song from â€œTop Gun.â€


	A watermark in the video indicates that it was created by someone with the handle @xerias_x. An account on X (aka Twitter) with that name, whose profile pic shows Trump as Pepe the Frog, posted the video earlier Saturday.

	Here are stills from the AI â€œKing Trumpâ€ feces-bombing clip:



	

	



	Among other videos Trump shared Saturday on Truth Social was one originally posted earlier in the day on BlueSky by VP JD Vance that shows Trump placing a crown on his own head and then drawing a sword. That one is set to the song â€œHail to the Kingâ€ by heavy metal band Avenged Sevenfold.

	Meanwhile, the official White House account on X marked â€œNo Kingsâ€ day by posting an image of Trump and Vance wearing crowns above an image of House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries and Sen. Chuck Schumer, the Democratic Senate Minority Leader, wearing sombreros.
	

	â€œWeâ€™re built different. Have a good night, everyone. ğŸ‘‘,â€ the caption of the White House post said.


	On Saturday, Oct. 18, nearly 7 million people participated at more than 2,700 â€œNo Kingsâ€ protests in all 50 states, CNN reported. Celebrities including Mark Ruffalo, Jimmy Kimmel, Robert De Niro and Glenn Close shared support for the protests against the Trump administrationâ€™s actions.

	Itâ€™s the latest weird AI-generated meme Trump has posted on social media over the years.

	In May, Trump shared an AI-generated image of himself dressed as the Pope,Â followingÂ the death of Pope FrancisÂ on April 21 (and a few days before Chicago-bornÂ Pope Leo XIV was elected). On this yearâ€™s May the 4th, aka â€œStar Wars Day,â€ the White House posted an AI-generated image of Trump as a brawny Jedi (although the presidentâ€™s lightsaber is red, which signifies the hateful and power-mad dark side of the Force in the Star Wars universe).

	In February, Trump shared an AI-generated videoÂ depicting the war-torn Gaza Strip transformed into the â€œTrump Gazaâ€ resort, which among other scenes showed Trump and Israel Prime Minister Benjamin NetanyahuÂ sitting shirtless poolside.Â 

	Ahead of the 2024 U.S. presidential election, Trump posted aÂ series of AI-generated images falsely claiming that Taylor SwiftÂ endorsed him for president, including one portraying the singer as Uncle Sam overlaid with a message that said â€œTaylor wants you to vote forÂ Donald Trump.â€Â Trump last summer also shared a photoshopped picture ofÂ himself as Superman alongside various associates as DC superheroes.

	RELATED: Jimmy Kimmel, Robert De Niro, Glenn Close and More Speak Out in Support of No Kings Protests: â€˜Weâ€™re Rising Up Againâ€™

schema.headline: Donald Trump Posts Bizarre AI Video of Himself in a â€˜King Trumpâ€™ Fighter Jet  Bombing NYC Protestors With Streams of Brown Liquid

title: Sabrina Carpenter Sings Two F-Words Uncensored on â€˜SNLâ€™ While Performing â€˜Nobodyâ€™s Sonâ€™
description: Sabrina Carpenter delivered an NSFW performance on the Oct. 18 episode of â€œSaturday Night Live,â€ when she sang her â€œManâ€™s Best Friendâ€ track â€œNobody
body:
Sabrina Carpenter delivered an NSFW performance on the Oct. 18 episode of â€œSaturday Night Live,â€ when she sang her â€œManâ€™s Best Friendâ€ track â€œNobodyâ€™s Songâ€ and didnâ€™t self-censor the lyrics â€œHe sure fucked me upâ€ on two occasions.

	There was likely some miscommunication with NBC censors, as the profanity wasnâ€™t muted or bleeped either time, causing it to go live uncensored on both the East Coast network broadcast and the Peacock simulcast. Some viewers on the West Coast noted that the broadcast seemed to be on a slight delay and had the audio go silent in their feed during the two F-words.
	

	Carpenter served as both the host and musical guest of the show, and the â€œNobodyâ€™s Songâ€ performance, with a martial arts stage setup, happened near the end of the show. Earlier in the evening, she sang â€œManchildâ€ as her first musical number.


	Carpenter recently used some surprise profanity on television during the 2025 VMAs while accepting the Best Album Award, where she said, â€œThis world, as we all know, can be so full of criticism and discrimination and negativity. So to get to be a part of something so often, more than not, that is something that can bring you light, make you smile, make you dance and make you feel like the world is your fucking oyster, I am so grateful, so grateful to do that.â€

	Off-the-cuff profanity has been much-discussed during â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ history, with it being an open secret that NBC and creator Lorne Michaels donâ€™t appreciate the show being opened up to potential FCC fines. Hosts like Kristen Stewart, Sam Rockwell and Ariana Grande have all dropped uncensored profanity during their monologues or sketches. Cast members such as Norm Macdonald and Jenny Slate have as well. The rock band the Replacements also dropped an F-bomb while performing in 1986.
	

	Meanwhile, the show has hosted plenty of controversial musical performances, such as NBC removing upside-down American flags from Rage Against the Machineâ€™s amps in 1996 to Ashlee Simpsonâ€™s botched vocal performance in 2004.

	Carpenter was not the only one to stir controversy by dropping the F-word in a high-profile setting in the last week. President Donald J. Trump used the word on Friday during a live news conference, saying that Venezuelan President Nicolas MaduroÂ â€œdoesnâ€™t want to fuck around with the United States.â€ Rather than  shrink back from the rough language, the official White House X account and the administrationâ€™s rapid response team account both posted video of the presidentâ€™s tough talk.

schema.headline: Sabrina Carpenter Sings Two F-Words Uncensored on â€˜SNLâ€™ While Performing â€˜Nobodyâ€™s Sonâ€™

title: London Film Festival Awards: Lucrecia Martelâ€™s â€˜Landmarksâ€™ Wins Best Film
description:
Oct 19, 2025 6:00am PT	
	

			


			
			
	

									Courtesy of The Match Factory
	

		
	
				
	Lucrecia Martelâ€˜s documentary â€œLandmar
body:
Oct 19, 2025 6:00am PT	
	

			


			
			
	

									Courtesy of The Match Factory
	

		
	
				
	Lucrecia Martelâ€˜s documentary â€œLandmarksâ€ (â€œNuestra Tierraâ€) was awarded best film in the official competition of this yearâ€™s London Film Festival. 

	â€œLandmarksâ€ explores the murder of Indigenous leader Javier Chocobar and the legacy of colonialism in Latin America. Of selecting the film, the competition jury â€” which was led by president Elizabeth Karlsen â€” said: â€œWith deep empathy and extraordinary journalistic and cinematic rigor, the director Lucrecia Martel dives deep into the events surrounding the 2009 murder of the Chuschagasta leader Javier Chocobar, in Argentinaâ€™s TucumÃ¡n Province. In foregrounding present-day voices and neglected histories, Martel emerges with a portrait of â€” and for â€” an Indigenous community, and grants them a measure of the justice the courts have long denied them. Within a remarkably strong competition, our jury is proud to honor this singular achievement.â€
	

	Elsewhere, Vincho Nchoguâ€™s â€œOne Woman One Braâ€ â€” a humorous account of one womanâ€™s fight to keep her ancestral land â€” was awarded the Sutherland Award for best first feature. David Bingongâ€™s â€œThe Travelers,â€ an intimate and hopeful account of the dangerous journey taken by a group of migrants from Cameroon to Europe, won the documentary competition. The short film competition winner was Said Zaghaâ€™s â€œCoyotes,â€ which follows a Palestinian doctorâ€™s journey after Israeli soldiers interrupt her commute home. 


	London Film Festival comes to a close on Sunday night with the U.K. premiere of Julia Jackmanâ€™s fantasy fairytale â€œ100 Nights of Hero.â€ Meanwhile, voting for the LFF Audience Awards will continue through Monday and the winners of best feature film and British feature film will be announced soon.


	
		More from Variety

schema.headline: London Film Festival Awards: Lucrecia Martelâ€™s â€˜Landmarksâ€™ Wins Best Film

title: Action Legend John Woo Relives His Hong Kong Days, as Hard-to-See â€˜Hard Boiledâ€™ and â€˜The Killerâ€™ Get Another Shot With Audiences
description: We take it for granted today, but John Woo has one of the most recognizable visual styles of any living filmmaker. Back in the mid-1980s, what start
body:
We take it for granted today, but John Woo has one of the most recognizable visual styles of any living filmmaker. Back in the mid-1980s, what started in Hong Kong reverberated around the world, as Woo â€” who was then stuck at the lowest point of his career â€” elevated action to art, finding poetry in the mediumâ€™s most destructive genre.

	For many years, and for no good reason, it was all but impossible for international audiences to see the three John Woo movies that saved his career, launched Chow Yun-fat to stardom and revolutionized action cinema forever. They are, in chronological order, â€œA Better Tomorrowâ€ (1986), â€œThe Killerâ€ (1989) and â€œHard Boiledâ€ (1992), and all three are playing in stunning 4K restorations this week at the LumiÃ¨re Festival in Lyon, France, where Woo will be on hand to introduce his first three masterpieces.
	

	Before flying overseas, the 79-year-old legend was gracious enough to welcome me into his headquarters in West Los Angeles, which overlooks the Getty Museum. The suite offers a panoramic view of the city Woo now calls home, and yet I found myself staring at the walls, on which hang giant posters for his most influential movies.


	In the corner, separated by a tall glass wall â€” the kind itâ€™s easy to imagine Chow crashing through in slow motion, with guns blazing in both hands â€” Wooâ€™s office is decorated with enormous posters for two classics by French director Jean-Pierre Melville: â€œLe Cercle Rouge,â€ with Alain Delon, and â€œLâ€™AÃ®nÃ© des Ferchaux,â€ starring Jean-Pierre Belmondo. I can tell this is going to be a good conversation, since Melville is my favorite director, too.
	

	â€œWhen I was young, I wrote quite a lot of poems,â€ Woo tells me. â€œI have always imagined that no matter what happens in this world, there is always some kind of beauty existing. And I also like romanticism. My style was greatly influenced by European movies, and especially Jacques Demyâ€™s movie, â€˜The Umbrellas of Cherbourg.â€™â€

	This isnâ€™t what I expected to hear. With Woo, the connection to French crime films is clear: Melville was obsessive about American genre cinema. He studied, absorbed and ultimately improved upon the codes in such film noir classics as â€œThis Gun for Hireâ€ and â€œOdds Against Tomorrow.â€ Decades later, Woo did the same with Melvilleâ€™s movies (â€œLe SamouraÃ¯â€ and â€œLe Cercle Rougeâ€ in particular).

	But a musical like â€œThe Umbrellas of Cherbourg,â€ which explodes with color and ends in tears? Itâ€™s not the first reference that comes to mind. Sam Peckinpahâ€™s â€œThe Wild Bunchâ€ or Martin Scorsese? Thatâ€™s more like it. Woo synthesizes all these influences into a fluid, elegant approach.

	â€œWhen Iâ€™m making an action movie, I donâ€™t see it as an action movie,â€ Woo explains. â€œItâ€™s like a painting or a poem, sometimes even like a musical. Iâ€™m aiming for that kind of feel, because Iâ€™m a dreamer. I think thatâ€™s my style because I always have some kind of beautiful dream in my mind.â€

	Wooâ€™s first filmmaking job was working as assistant director for Shaw Brothers veteran Chang Cheh. At a time when the Hong Kong industry was dominated by sex comedies and kung fu movies, Chang taught him the principles of dynamic action. And though he never studied any of the martial arts, Woo has always loved dance, which made all the difference in how he stages gun battles.

	â€œI was a pretty good dancer when I was young,â€ says Woo, who choreographs the balletic action scenes in his films himself. â€œWhen it comes to the action in a movie, itâ€™s all about the beauty of the body movement and the fighting skill.â€

	In the 1970s, Woo had a successful run directing comedies and other projects that might now seem off-brand to his fans, like the 1976 Cantonese opera â€œPrincess Chang Pingâ€ and low-budget action comedy â€œMoney Crazy.â€ That changed in the early â€™80s, when Woo hit a rough patch. â€œMy movies didnâ€™t work at all, and then I became a box office poison,â€ he says with a chuckle. â€œI was looked down on by so many people, and some of my friends even said I should retire.â€
	

	Meanwhile, Wooâ€™s friend and fellow director Tsui Hark was on a hot streak, which put him in the ideal position with Golden Princess, a new production company with money to spend and limited experience in cinema. Unhappy to see talented peers unable to find work, Tsui used the opportunity to produce projects for Woo and others.

	â€œHeâ€™s a good man,â€ Woo says. â€œHe liked helping the others, so if he saw anyone out of a job who couldnâ€™t get a movie, he supported them.â€ It was Tsuiâ€™s idea to make a gangster movie that a family audience could watch â€” what became â€œA Better Tomorrowâ€ â€” which Tsui would produce and Woo could direct.

	â€œThat was my first auteur film,â€ Woo recalls. â€œHe encouraged me to put myself into the movie, to make the movie my own. And he let me change all the dialogue, to say what I really wanted to say from my heart.â€

	For years, Woo had been wanting to make a film like â€œLe SamouraÃ¯,â€ but no one would give him the opportunity. At last, he was being given the green light to incorporate his personal style into a project, dressing Chow in a stiff trench coat â€” a nod to both Alain Delon and his favorite Japanese star, Ken Takakura â€” and giving the character a strict code of honor that would become a Woo signature. (At the time, the director felt the younger generation had lost appreciation for traditional morals, so he designed the dynamic between Chow and Ti Lungâ€™s characters â€” which reminded Chinese audiences of the bond they felt toward old schoolmates â€” to reinforce the values of brotherhood, friendship and sacrifice.)

	â€œBefore â€˜A Better Tomorrow,â€™ I didnâ€™t have much chance to try this kind of a style. Because I never got any support from the studio or anyone, I wasnâ€™t able to experiment,â€ he says.

	Working with Tsui for Golden Princess was different. So long as the films were profitable, the financiers left them alone.

	â€œWe had a lot of creative freedom,â€ Woo remembers. â€œThere was a trust between us, so we could do whatever we wanted, so every director, they had a great opportunity to try something new, something they had never done before.â€

	As far as the investors were concerned, Tsui and Woo knew the market. By keeping the budgets tight, they could be reasonably sure the films would break even â€” and many were wildly successful (â€œA Better Tomorrowâ€ broke all box office records in Hong Kong, prompting a sequel, even though Chowâ€™s character had been killed in the original).
	

	â€œSince we were trusting each other, there was no need to give them a completed script. We just let them know the idea, the rough budget and the shooting schedule,â€ Woo says. â€œTheir main concern was about the casting, if you can find somebody who could guarantee you make money.â€

	Working for Chang back in the day, Woo had watched his mentor turn unknown actors into stars. And of course, he had developed his own strategies over the years. â€œI know how to use all kind of tools to help the actors,â€ he says. â€œI know what kind of lens will make him look good and what kind of angle. And the size will bring out his very special quality.â€

	With Chow, Woo saw something in the actor (who was a popular TV star, but nothing on the level of what followed) no one else had. Watching a show called â€œThe Bund,â€ Woo noticed how the actorâ€™s eyes helped tell the story and cast him against type as a triad gangster given a chance to redeem himself.

	â€œHe had never punched a guy in his whole life,â€ says Woo, who tailors the action to each actor he works with. He might try to find out what sports a given performer prefers â€” like running or swimming â€” and then model his movement accordingly, incorporating that into his choreography. Woo even considers the size of his actorsâ€™ trigger finger when selecting the right guns for them to use in a shootout. â€œIf heâ€™s got a long finger, then he could be holding a little bit bigger guns. If he has a short finger like me, then heâ€™ll hold a pistol, not too long.â€

	One of Wooâ€™s trademarks â€” actors holding two handguns, firing with both barrels at the same time â€” has an unexpected origin. â€œIâ€™d seen a lot of Westerns,â€ Woo says, but he wasnâ€™t thinking of cowboys with holsters on each hip. On â€œA Better Tomorrow,â€ he wanted to shoot the definitive gun battle in Hong Kong movie history, but Woo figured, â€œif heâ€™s a professional killer and heâ€™s a true hero, he would never use a machine gun. Itâ€™s too easy and not elegant.â€

	Woo had a clear idea of the sound he wanted â€” he could hear the drumbeat in his head â€” but had never owned a gun in his life, so he asked the props team for help. The weapons experts suggested a semiautomatic Beretta 92F handgun that could fire up to 15 rounds nonstop, though the tempo wasnâ€™t fast enough. Then Woo had an idea: â€œHow about using two guns?â€ By staggering the rhythm, where Chow alternated pulling the trigger with each hand, Woo got the â€œmusicâ€ he wanted.
	

	â€œA Better Tomorrowâ€ was a huge hit in Hong Kong, which gave Woo a chance to make several more movies for Golden Princess. He had even more creative control on â€œThe Killer.â€ Tsui was busy producing other films at the time, leaving Woo to do what he wanted â€” which, in this case, was a poetic hitman movie, Ã  la Melvilleâ€™s â€œLe SamouraÃ¯,â€ where an assassin sacrifices himself for the lounge singer who witnesses his crime.

	â€œI had the whole movie in my mind,â€ says Woo, who shot without a script, instructing the actors and crew what he wanted with each scene on set. According to the director, they thought he was making another â€œBetter Tomorrowâ€ and werenâ€™t expecting something so romantic.

	When â€œThe Killerâ€ was invited to screen at the Toronto Film Festival, Woo was instantly recognized as a visionary talent by international critics. The directorâ€™s most bombastic movie by far, â€œHard Boiledâ€ made him an even hotter commodity abroad. The plot was inspired by a Japanese news report that had deeply disturbed Woo, about a lunatic guilty of poisoning baby formula. Ever the moralist (despite the level of violence in his films), Woo flipped the idea to focus on two cops who wind up protecting innocent hospital patients â€” including a ward full of newborn babies â€” from a ruthless triad boss.

	â€œWhat surprised me was how it got such a warm welcome from the Western world,â€ says Woo, who started to get offers to work in Hollywood.

	â€œThe biggest reason I came to Hollywood was because I wanted to learn something new. At the same time, I tried to prove my style could also work in a Hollywood movie,â€ says Woo, whose action-movie innovations â€” slow-motion cinematography, gravity-defying choreography, over-the-top pyrotechnics â€” were already influencing Western directors like Robert Rodriguez and Luc Besson.

	Woo wasnâ€™t quite prepared for how much stricter the American industry was about everything, from second-guessing the director to how violence is depicted. (His first Hollywood feature, â€œHard Target,â€ earned an NC-17 rating on that front.)

	In America, Woo observes, â€œThe studio and the big star had so much control. They have final approval of the script and the supporting roles. But in Hong Kong, the director is everything.â€
	

	On â€œHard Target,â€ Belgian bodybuilder-cum-action hero Jean-Claude Van Damme wanted a say in how Woo cut the footage. The Hong Kong helmer was lucky to have producers Sam Raimi, Jim Jacks and Rob Tapert in his corner. â€œWhen the star tried to control the editing, they threw him out,â€ he says.

	Wooâ€™s best American studio experience was making â€œFace/Off,â€ which had been conceived as a more overtly sci-fi scenario set 200 years in the future. Woo wasnâ€™t comfortable with that genre or the visual effects it would have required, so it was rewritten as a more contemporary â€œhuman dramaâ€ (in Wooâ€™s words).

	What made it so satisfying, apart from all that stars John Travolta and Nicolas Cage brought to their characters, was having the full support of Paramount chairman Sherry Lansing. The way Woo tells it, Lansing gathered the entire crew at the outset and told the room, â€œAll I want is a John Woo movie. So no one should give him any notes.â€

	But there was a harsh trade-off for all the creative freedom Woo had enjoyed in Hong Kong: Golden Princess owned the rights to all the films he and Tsui had made, which they parceled up and sold to different territories. Then the company went under, and the films fell out of circulation in most parts of the world. â€œSo the Hong Kong movies we had made became just like a memory,â€ says Woo, whoâ€™s delighted to see them finally restored and back in circulation, since Shout! Studios acquired the Golden Princess library earlier this year.

	The reason Woo was able to remake â€œThe Killerâ€ last year can be explained by a fluke over film rights: Nearly three decades ago, Columbia had wanted to do an American â€œcoverâ€ version, but couldnâ€™t get it off the ground. Many screenwriters and directors had come and gone from the project, without success.

	â€œIt never came together. And then after 20 years, they gave the rights back to us,â€ Woo says. He was working in China, shooting â€œRed Cliffâ€ at the time, but he was intrigued by Brian Helgelandâ€™s idea of gender-flipping the killer, so Chow Yun-fatâ€™s character would be a woman.

	â€œWhen I came back, I really got excited, because I had never considered a female killer before,â€ he says.

	According to Woo, his biggest regret about the Golden Princess period â€” and the film heâ€™ll never be able to fully recover â€” is 1990â€™s â€œBullet in the Headâ€ (the film he made between â€œThe Killerâ€ and â€œHard Boiledâ€).
	

	â€œThe original cut was three hours, but for the Hong Kong release, I was forced to cut it down to two hours,â€ he explains. Woo had to slash several scenes he was proud of to appease the producers. Once Woo came to Hollywood and had earned enough money, he tried to buy the rights to the movie, but it was too late: The Hong Kong lab that held onto the deleted footage had thrown it out after a year. â€œThey only get saved for one year, and then they are thrown away like garbage,â€ he says.

	The good news is that Wooâ€™s other Golden Princess projects have survived and can now be rediscovered by audiences who grew up on â€œThe Matrixâ€ and the John Wick movies.

schema.headline: Action Legend John Woo Relives His Hong Kong Days, as Hard-to-See â€˜Hard Boiledâ€™ and â€˜The Killerâ€™ Get Another Shot With Audiences

title: Sabrina Carpenter Jokes About Provocative Image in â€˜SNLâ€™ Monologue:Â â€˜Iâ€™m Not Just Horny, Iâ€™m Also Turned On and Sexually Chargedâ€™
description: Sabrina Carpenter, the host as well as musical guest for this weekâ€™s â€œSaturday Night Live,â€ used her monologue to riff on her risque image, suggesti
body:
Sabrina Carpenter, the host as well as musical guest for this weekâ€™s â€œSaturday Night Live,â€ used her monologue to riff on her risque image, suggesting that she wants to be known for more than just being sexually provocative, while of course joking that she indeed has a one-track mind.

	â€œNow since Iâ€™m here, I want to clear up some misconceptions people have about me,â€ Carpenter said. â€œEveryone thinks of me as this, like, horndog pop star, but thereâ€™s really so much more to me. Iâ€™m not just horny. Iâ€™m also turned on and Iâ€™m sexually charged. And I love to read. My favorite book is the encyclopedia. Itâ€™s so big and itâ€™s hardâ€¦â€
	

	The pop star showed the controversial cover photo of her recent â€œManâ€™s Best Friendâ€ album. â€œSome people got a little freaked out by the cover. Iâ€™m not sure why,â€ she said. â€œIt was just this me on all fours with an unseen figure pulling my hair,. But what people donâ€™t realize is, thatâ€™s just how they cropped it. If you zoom out, itâ€™s clearly a picture from the 50th anniversary special of Bowen (Yang) helping me up by the hairâ€¦â€ The image zoomed out further: â€œâ€¦after Martin Short shoved me out of the buffet line.â€


	In any case, Carpenter avowed, â€œThere is a real person underneath all the sparkles and the wigs and the corsets. And another thing you might not know about me is that I love to interact with the audience during my show.â€ She took to the crowd, interacting with a young man who identified himself as Will from Maryland â€” both of which, naturally, turned her on. â€œOoh, what a sexy, unusual place. See, I love talking to normal people. Theyâ€™re so fascinating when theyâ€™re real like you.â€
	


	But when she asked what the audience member did for a living, and he answered â€œventure capital,â€ she quickly moved on.

	â€œThe last one thing I like to do at my concerts is arrest someone for being hot. So who here can I arrest tonight?â€ Kenan Thompson came out with a pair of pink handcuffs, saying he was arresting her not for being hot but â€œfor falsely impersonating an officer 200 times at your concerts.â€

	Thompson said he was actually there to get a Cameo for his daughter, only to have Carpenter tell him that would cost $200,000â€³ â€” and while he moved on, she announced that â€œif anyone else wants one, find me on Venmo.â€

	The monologue followed an opening Domingo sketch in which Carpenter was one of several women at a birthday party describing a bachelorette-style trip to Nashville while singing spoof versions of Taylor Swiftâ€™s â€œThe Fate of Opheliaâ€ and Lady Gagaâ€™s â€œAbracadabra.â€

	Later, for her first musical number, Carpenter sang her No. 1 hit â€œManchildâ€ with girlish glee on a stage decked out as a bedroom, bouncing around on a bed in a yellow â€œSNLâ€ T-shirt and pink â€œSNLâ€ underwear, surrounded on either side by the band and eventually joined in the foreground by a sax soloist. 

	The second musical number, â€œNobodyâ€™s Son,â€ had Carpenter singing in a martial-arts setting, Controversy arose as the east coast feed had her singing the words â€œfucked upâ€ twice, uncensored. West coast viewers, however, reported that the audio went silent in those two instances, with censors apparently having more of a tape delay for that feed.

schema.headline: Sabrina Carpenter Jokes About Provocative Image in â€˜SNLâ€™ Monologue:Â â€˜Iâ€™m Not Just Horny, Iâ€™m Also Turned On and Sexually Chargedâ€™

title: Donald Trump Celebrates Todayâ€™s â€˜Yes King Marchâ€™ on â€˜SNLâ€™: â€˜People Are Marchingâ€™ Because I Freed â€˜Liarâ€™ George Santos From Prison
description: James Austin Johnsonâ€™s Donald Trump dropped by an episode of the junk food podcast â€œSnack Homiezâ€ during the Sabrina Carpenter-hosted episode of â€œSa
body:
James Austin Johnsonâ€™s Donald Trump dropped by an episode of the junk food podcast â€œSnack Homiezâ€ during the Sabrina Carpenter-hosted episode of â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ on Oct. 18.

	When asked by young men co-hosting the podcast â€”Â played by Carpenter, Chloe Fineman, Jane Wickline and Veronika Slowikowska â€”Â about his thoughts on the candy Airheads, he had a predictably long-winded answer that touched on the dayâ€™s â€œNo Kingsâ€ protests and the presidentâ€™s recent move to release disgraced former Republican congressman George Santos from prison. 
	

	â€œYou know who I like is that George Santos,â€ Trump said. â€œHeâ€™s weird, heâ€™s a liar. I think heâ€™s great. We donâ€™t know anything about him, heâ€™s one of our favorite people. I donâ€™t know him at all, but one of our favorite people. People are marching because theyâ€™re happy heâ€™s free. Itâ€™s a â€˜Yes, King!â€™ march. They say, â€˜Yes, King!'â€


	Trump didnâ€™t appear in the eveningâ€™s cold open, which is usually the case. The episode started about 14 minutes late due to college football running long, and the show began with a reprisal of the fan-favorite sketch â€œDomingoâ€ instead of beginning with a traditional political cold open.

	Santos was also mentioned at the top of the episodeâ€™s Weekend Update segment, with Colin Jost joking, â€œYesterday, President Trump finally released what everyone has been asking him to release: George Santos, the former Republican congressman who pled guilty to fraud and something called â€˜aggravated identity theft,â€™ which I think is when you push someone in a closet and change clothes with them.â€
	

	Watch the â€œSnack Homiezâ€ sketch below.

schema.headline: Donald Trump Celebrates Todayâ€™s â€˜Yes King Marchâ€™ on â€˜SNLâ€™: â€˜People Are Marchingâ€™ Because I Freed â€˜Liarâ€™ George Santos From Prison

title: Kim Kardashian Breaks Down Her â€˜Last-Minuteâ€™ Academy Museum Gala Face Mask Look: Had â€˜Full Hair and Makeupâ€™ Underneath (EXCLUSIVE)
description:
Kim Kardashian couldnâ€™t see a thing when she arrived at the Academy Museum Gala on Saturday night in Los Angeles â€“ for good reason.

	Her head was e
body:
Kim Kardashian couldnâ€™t see a thing when she arrived at the Academy Museum Gala on Saturday night in Los Angeles â€“ for good reason.

	Her head was entirely covered by a face mask.

	â€œMargiela couture,â€ Kardashian told me exclusively on the red carpet. â€œ[Designer] Glenn Martens. You know, I love Margiela. I flew in my favorite makeup artist Mario from New York, and this is kind of a last-minute thing, so Iâ€™m sure heâ€™s not so happy with it.â€
	

	She says she was in â€œfull hair and makeupâ€ underneath the mask, which she was planning on taking off once inside the gala.

	â€œIt does look very Skims-y,â€ Kardashian said, referring to her underwear line. â€œThatâ€™s why I was drawn to it when the Margiela couture show came out. I saw this look and I was like, â€˜That is so Skims to me.â€™â€



	

					Kim Kardashian at the Academy Museum Gala.
									WWD via Getty Images
	



	Speaking of Skims, I asked Kardashian about her new limited line of $32 merkins. Officially called â€œfaux hair micro string thongs,â€ they sold out within minutes of going on sale. â€œThat was just a fun idea that I had. There was a shoot, and someone wanted to, like, have hair down there once. And I was like, â€˜Couldnâ€™t this just be easy and have it on a thong?â€™ And so we made that happen. I had no idea that it would get that reaction and sell out in a few minutes.â€

	Itâ€™s not known yet if Kardashian took off the mask for the nightâ€™s dinner and program.

	This yearâ€™s gale honorees included PenÃ©lope Cruz,Â Walter Salles,Â Bruce Springsteen andÂ Bowen Yang.Â  Presented by Rolex, the star-studded evening raises vital support for the museumâ€™s exhibitions, screenings, and educational programming.
	

	The 2025 Gala Host Committee included Amy Adams, Judd Apatow, Gael GarcÃ­a Bernal, Laura Dern, Colman Domingo, Willem Dafoe, Goldie Hawn, Oscar Isaac, ZoÃ« Kravitz, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Lupita Nyongâ€™o, Jenna Ortega, Winona Ryder, ChloÃ« Sevigny, Tessa Thompson, Rachel Zegler and many more.

title: Sexy Stars Decked Out in Disney Costumes
description:
Sexy Stars
                          All Decked Out
                          In Disney Costumes!
body:
Sexy Stars
                          All Decked Out
                          In Disney Costumes!
                      
                  
                        Published October 19, 2025 7:00 AM PDT
                                                                            
      
    
          Halloween's just around the corner, folks, and we figured we'd get into the swing of things ... with a gallery of sexy celebs wearing Disney costumes!
      
    
          It's just a little something-something to get you in the spirit of the season, and if we can't do it for ya ... maybe Bernice Burgos, Alix Earle, and Kendall Jenner all decked out like characters from the House of Mouse will!
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          If there's anyone you're trying to impress, maybe take after Casey Boonstra and dress up like Ariel ... we're sure that special someone will wanna be "Part of Your World!"
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Or, you can keep it classic, just like Milania Giudice, who we think was the Belle of the ball while wearing her Disney costume!
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Oh, and here's a little tip ... DIY costumes can be way cooler than store-bought ones, and we included a shot of Dixie D'Amelio all dressed up like the Queen of Hearts in case you needed a little inspiration!
      
      
              
          
                          
                Disney
              
                          
                Halloween

body:
Guess Who This
                          Forward-Thinking Singer Is!
                      
                  
                        Published October 18, 2025 4:00 PM PDT
                                                                            
      
    
      
        
                    
                  
      
                    TMZ.com
          
    
          We know plenty of artists are on the fence about the effects of A.I. on the music industry -- and we wanna see if you can guess who this forward-thinking singer is!
      
    
          We caught up with this guy at LAX in May this year, and he was pretty open about not being too afraid of A.I. -- because he claimed no one could do it like he can!
      
    
          Still, he admitted we're likely gonna need a few rules to make sure A.I. doesn't completely replace artists in the future ... and to be fair, we're not sure anyone but this guy could have written a banger like "Closer!"

title: Louvre Museum Closed After Major Jewelry Heist
description:
Louvre Museum
                          Closed After Thieves Steal Jewels
body:
Louvre Museum
                          Closed After Thieves Steal Jewels
                      
                  
                        Published October 19, 2025 5:08 AM PDT
                                                                      |
                Updated October 19, 2025 6:35 AM PDT
                                    
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          A major heist rocked The Louvre over the weekend when thieves scaled the iconic Paris museum with a basket lift and made off with priceless jewels in just seven minutes.
      
    
          According to Le Parisien, the thieves targeted the Apollo Gallery, using a freight elevator to reach the jewelry collection of Napoleon and Empress EugÃ©nie. The outlet says nine pieces were stolen, including EugÃ©nie's crown which was later found broken outside the museum.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Franceâ€™s Interior Minister Laurent NuÃ±ez called it a "major robbery," saying the crew entered from the outside using a basket lift and swiped gems of inestimable value. The job was "clearly carried out by a team that had done scouting," NuÃ±ez said, noting the panes were cut with a disc cutter.
      

                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          The Louvre, the worldâ€™s most visited museum, shut its doors "for exceptional reasons" after the break in. Images from the scene showed confused crowds as police sealed off the gates and surrounding streets near the palace complex.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          The Louvre has weathered infamous thefts before including the 1911 Mona Lisa heist that turned Da Vinci's masterpiece into the world's most famous painting. But Sundayâ€™s smash and grab adds another chapter to its storied history.

title: Brandy Walks Off Stage Mid-Concert, Monica Left to Finish Alone
body:
Brandy
                          Unexpectedly Leaves Stage Mid-Concert
                      
                  
                        Published October 19, 2025 8:00 AM PDT
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Brandy and Monica's The Boy Is Mine Tour hit a snag Saturday night when Brandy abruptly walked off stage mid performance, leaving Monica to close the show solo.
      
    
          The R&B legends were performing at Chicago's United Center when Brandy appeared frustrated by sound issues and stopped mid song.
      
    
      
      This was literally the last we saw of Brandy in Chicago. #theboyisminetour pic.twitter.com/CMv0e3xDHFâ€” Mike (@LikeMike2Day) October 19, 2025
              @LikeMike2Day
          
  
    
          "Give me one second y'all, I gotta get my ..." she told the crowd before walking backstage.
      

          But Brandy never returned and after several minutes of confusion, Monica carried on alone and wrapped the night without performing their 1998 duet, "The Boy Is Mine."
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Fans flooded social media with clips and questions, wondering why the show ended early. Saturdayâ€™s hiccup comes just months after the pair announced their reunion tour marking more than two decades since their hit single made music history and years after their highly publicized feud.
      
    
          No official word yet from either artist on what caused Brandy's early exit. We've reached out to reps for Brandy and Monica ... so far, no word back.
